newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian Eles sees lower 1996 profit.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian Eles sees lower 1996 profit.

text.p: Slovenia's electricity distributor Eles said on Tuesday it expected to post lower profits in 1996 due to high maintenance costs and low prices of electricity.
"Profits will be just above zero, down from last year's 200 million tolars ($1.4 million)," Ivo Banic, general manager of Eles told Reuters.
Banic said turnover in 1996 rose to 75 billion tolars ($528.2 million) from 70 billion in 1995.
"In 1996 we invested some 1.5 billion tolars from one billion in the previous year but most of it was spent on the maintenance of existing facilities," Banic said.

He pointed out that electricity prices in Slovenia are 40 percent lower than the average price in the European Union. Earlier this year, parliament agreed to lift electricity prices each year by seven percent in order to reach the EU average in 2001.
However, since the government allowed only a 2.6 percent increase in prices this year, Eles is calling for a 9.6 percent increase from January and another 9.6 percent increase from March 1997.

"If the government would stick to the agreement and raise prices at least by seven percent each year, Eles would soon be able to invest in the construction of new facilities," Banic said. -- Novica Mihajlovic, Lubljana newsroom, 386-61-125-8439
